title: Can I cover songs in YouTube because I don't understand this ? - Quora

response.answer_text: ORIGINAL QUESTION: “Can I cover songs in YouTube because I don't understand this ?” Alright. The way the question is worded is a bit vague, so it seems likely you’re asking one of two things. The first is that you’re essentially asking how to make cover music. I’m not going to answer this one in detail at the moment as there is a LOT of material out there that is easy to approach, and laid out simply. The second option, however, is what I’ll be focusing on, as it is VERY confusing, and took me quite a while to be clear on how it all worked. That is: MY REWORDED QUESTION: “What are the rules and/or restrictions on making cover songs on YouTube (getting permissions) Copyright law is very confusing, and all over the place when it comes to YouTube and cover music, mainly because what it says and what is generally accepted are so different as to be laughable. There’s quite a bit of information to cover, so I’ll hit it point by point and try to have one single, cohesive answer.  THE LAW REGARDING A MECHANICAL LICENSE:There are two types of Copyright licenses that apply to cover music. First, there is a Mechanical License, which allows an artist to cover and distribute (sell) music digitally. This includes selling CDs, on Spotify, Pandora, etc. A Mechanical License is obtained by paying a certain fee to the Agency that releases the original music. Once paid, you are free to cover. It is pretty easy to obtain this, but more on that later.THE LAW REGARDING A SYNCHRONIZATION LICENSE:This is where things get tricky. According to law, if you are pairing the audio cover with video, and that means ANY video (You while singing, a Music Video, A pure black screen, anything), then you require a second type of license, the Synchronization License. This is were all the confusion comes from, because Publishers VERY rarely give these away, and technically EVERY YouTube cover needs one to be legal. However, because it’s so hard to get, this law is mostly ignored and nobody really ever does anything about it. There are still some aspects that you REALLY need to remember, so let’s get to that next.PRACTICAL APPLICATION - WHAT DO I NEED TO DO?Realistically, you really only need to do two things, Mark it as a cover of (original artist), and Do not monetize your videos. Technically, virtually every cover video on YouTube is illegal, but nobody really cares, since the covers ultimately help the original artist anyway, so they don’t care as long as the cover artists aren’t trying to make money. If all you want to do is create YouTube covers, and you don’t want to make money, then that’s it. You’ll notice that it is EXTREMELY rare to find a YouTube cover that has ads on it, and this is why.BUT WHAT IF I WANT TO MAKE MONEY ON MY COVER SONGS?Don’t worry! While it’s practically impossible to obtain the rights to make money from your covers on YouTube, you can still make money in other ways:DONATIONS (Patreon, Gofundmet, etc.):Legally, if you use a crowd-sourcing platform, you aren’t making money from the covers, and you’re in the clear. In fact, you can even ask for donations at the end of your cover video and still be clear. This doesn’t require any additional licenses, since people are just donating to you as an artist, and are not purchasing your covers from you. My guess is that in the next ten years or so, there will eventually be further legal restrictions placed on this method, but for now, you’re in the clear.OBTAINING A MECHANICAL LICENSE AND SELLING:So you can’t make money on your YouTube covers, but you can still sell the audio covers. All you have to do is obtain a Mechanical License, and then you’re in the clear to put your music on Spotify, iTunes, Pandora, etc., and make money!Traditionally, this was difficult to obtain, since you had to contact the Publishing company, and work out a deal with them for each of the mediums you planned to distribute to, and you had to do this for each song you covered, which was a nightmare. Now, however, there is a much simpler method:USE A 3RD PARTY LICENSING COMPANY (Hassle-Free Selling):All you have to do to start legally selling your money is to find a 3rd party licensing company (Loudr, CDBaby, Tunecore, HFA, etc.), sign up with their service, and start selling your music. They already have existing deals with most Music Publishers, so you don’t even have to go through a waiting process. All you have to do is upload your cover, select which song it is, and choose where to sell it (Spotify, iTunes, Amazon Prime Music, etc.). They will take a certain percentage of the profits, and the rest is yours. No hassle. That’s about it. While the world of copyrights and music goes so much further, and has more rules if you want to perform a cover song publicly for money, distribute physical copies, etc. chances are you won’t be needing to do that any time soon. Feel free to ask if you have any questions, and let me know if anything needs correcting. Thanks! Yes, you can cover songs on YouTube. The best way for you to do this is by getting a simple, free video editor. For this purpose, I’d recommend Windows Movie Maker which is free to download from the Microsoft Website. It really depends if you want to show your face in it. If you don’t it’s a whole lot easier. If you do it really depends on which options you choose. Here are the options. Playing music in the background while recording yourself.Open Movie Maker, and add the selected song into it. Then select record voice-over and record yourself. Note - You will not have your face in because it’s a whole lot harder.Same as above, but you’ll have to include a video of you.

If you’re asking about getting permission to cover a song, I really don’t know. I think it’s an issue but I see lots of covers on YouTube and I doubt all of them have gotten permission. If you’re not asking about that, I’m afraid I don’t know what you’re asking. (a2a)
